div.head: BOVRIL
div.p: Qu'est ce que c'est BOVRIL?
BOVRIL est le produit garanti du meilleur bétail qui existe.
C'est un repas à la minute qui protège contre les intempéries.
"BOVRIL" et "Bonne Cuisine" sont deux mots qui disent la même chose.

BOVRIL répond a une nécessité; il est non seulement une boisson delicieuse et saine, mais il est encore indispensable pour préparer instantanement des soupes et sauces appétisantes. Bovril n'a pas de rival pour corser les plats les plus récherches.
BOVRIL répare l'organisme fatigué.

div.head: Icilma.
div.p: ARABIC FOR "FLOWS THE WATER."

Icilma Fluor Cream is the only cream that contains no grease nor oil. Deliciously scented it cleanses the pores of the skin as nothing else can do, makes it pearly white, gives life to the tissues, elasticity to the muscles, and a deliciously cool feeling to the skin.

Its unique properties are due to Icilma Natural Water so that it may well be called Nature's Skin Food and the skin requires nothing else to give it the necessary vitality, to preserve it from sunburn, heat, cold or the effects of hard water, to prevent and cure the minor irritations due to overheated blood, and to preserve the youthful fresh look to which hot climates are so fatal.
Invaluable for immediately curing mosquito and insect bites and for greatly preventing them.
Depot for Egypt : J. McGregor, Chemist.
Alexandria, Cairo, Ibrahimieh, Luxor, Icilma Co. Ltd., 142, Gray's Inn Road, London, W. C.

div.head: SYRIAN OPINION ON "THE EGYPT OF THE FUTURE"
div.p: A Syrian resident in Cairo sends us the following interesting criticism on Mr Edward Dicoy's recent work "The Egypt of the Future : -

Mr. Edward Dicey's recent book "The Egypt of the Futuro," has at last given us, in a somewhat concrete form, the Nationalists' policy. It is, indeed, the first constructive elaboration, to my knowledge, of the Nationalist programme in an attenuated form. Mr. Robertson, M P., in his recent treatise, has very ably discussed the problem of Egypt ; but his argument was almost purely psychological and philosophical. In its abstract forın it is almost irrefutable, but in its practical application it seems to a man born in the East, and fully acquainted with the mentality of the Egyptians, and their social and political life, somewhat of a failure. I need hardly make any reference here to the innumerable | discussions of the Native Nationalist Press, | because full of beautiful sentiments as they are, they are nothing but the expression of wild impulses sometimes of real, but more often, of pseudo-patriotism, and we see in them none of the practical sense and logic which alone can form the basis for the materialization of a national cause. Therefore Mr. Dicey's book remains the sole work susceptible of palpable dissection. It is also the most deserving of study and como ant, in view of the knowledge of the author of Egyptian matters, and his long experience erived from local sources. I have not had the privilege yet to get hold of a copy of Mr. Dicey's book, but as in the conclusion reproduced in the "Egyptian Gazette" he outlines in a summary manner his proposed scheme, the same may be taken as a subject for the discussion thereof.

Mr. Dicey is very clear and categorical in his proposals. While he advocates the retention of supreme authority by the representative of the Protecting Power, he recommends I practically the wholesale dismissal of all British

officials and their substitution by native administrators. Ho refers to the latter as "the old native administrators." What class does he refer to ? Is it that one which existed before the Occupation and which consisted largely of Turks ? But this is not the point. We will assume that Mr Dicey would have these native administrators recruited from and elected by the people of Egypt ; but here is the crux of the problem. It would be quixotic to think of universal suffrage is the basis of a constitional autonomous government under foreign control. The overwhelming majority consists of absolutely illiterate thën steeped in primitive ignorance, and such of the new generation of fellaheen as are having their eyes opened to the light of an elementary education are scarcely qualified to have a voice in such a hypothetical elective system. Besides, supposing that a large section is educated and fitted for embodying constituencies organized on European lines, an elective system based on plurality of votes would still be inconvenient, not to say impossible, owing to the diversity of creeds and nationalities. And to propose a representative sýstem based on racial and religious divisions would place the problem farther than ever from the desired solution by Mr. Dicey, viz., the taking off of the sting of unpopularity. Besides, by far a great deal of the wealth of the land is in the hands now of foreigners, and what some fanatics have called "Intrus" ; and it is not conceivable that those who are at the head of the land's industrial and agricultural activities, and, indeed, control practically the finances of Egypt, should not only have almost no share in the internal administration, but be left at the tender mercies of the incompetent Moslem majority. Mr. Dicey may object that there is the representative of the Protecting Power to prevent abusus. But in his "for interieur" he who knows Egyptand the Egyptians so well must roulize that the position of the Representative under these abnormal and, indeed, impossible conditions would be untenable. The result, in so far as the susceptibilities of the Egyptians as a whole are concerned, would be worse than what Mr. Dicey now seems to deplore. I may repeat that Egypt is composed of too heterogeneous elements to admit of safe and proper administration, even of an internal kind, at the hands of the representatives of the large Moslem majority. I will not allude here to the qualifications of this majority as a whole for administrative ability, from motives of delicacy and broad toleration. It is easy to make proposals in the shape of principles and leave the working of the practical details to others, or rather to one, viz., the Resident.

Then Mr. Dicey would have us retain the old and obsolete laws and customs, and allow a considerable latitude to these native administrators in the discharge of their functions, not calling them even to account in case their administration be considered somewhat dif. ferent from the view entertained by the Protecting Power. This is tantamount to the sacrifice of a small yet all-important minority to a very large yet to a certain extent backward and negligible majority. In discussing problems of Egypt we must not lose sight of the fact that it is becoming more and more cosmopolitan, not to speak of the political importance of the country as a factor in the balance of power and the preservation of poace ; and just as in the days of the early Caliphate the land was conquered by the Moslems and appropriated by them, it is now, by the same law, p ssing into the stronger hand of European civilization under the guidance of England. The more rational viow would be that the lurge yet feeble majority should be taught and brought up to the level of the dominant and intelligent minority, without of course touching in any way religious susceptibilities. Foreigu, and we may say, international interests at stake in Egypt are too many and important to be jeopardized by such a change as is proposed, and that simply to avoid an unpopularity which, to a large extent, is un. warrantable, and may be perhaps got over by less drastic means.

div.head: DEATH OF MR. BARKER.
div.p: OLDEST BRITISH RESIDENT.

By the death of Mr. Henry Barker, the foander of the well-koowa firm of Barker and Co, which took place at his residenca ia Alexandria yesterday, the oldest member of the British Colony has passed away. Mr. Burkar died at 1 p.m. after only 24 hoors' illness. He had, however, been in failing health for å considerable time past, a fact whicb, nevertheless, did not prevent bim from taking an interest in offsire, and till within a day or two of his death he was a familiar figure in the city.

The late Mr. Barker was born on the Island of Saint Maura in the year 1829 and was therefore 78 years of age. He was the end of the late Edward Barker, sometime British Consul in Cairr, and came to this country as far back as 1849 D?0088ed was a shrewd busiDegg man and, in partnership with bis brotber, the late Mr. Frederiok Barker, founded shortly afterwards the firm of Barker and Company, at the herd of which he remained, taking an active interest to the last, till Septembor, 1908, when his fast fsiling health com. palled bim to ritire in favoar of his song. The late Mr. Barker held for over forty years the appointment of Swedi-b and Norwegian Consal at Alaxzodris, and on the diganion of the two Siates in 1905 948 ADpointed Consal Goneral for Norway. This appointment, how ive", he wog compelled to relinquish eurly last year owing to his health, and he h48 sinoe been 800409 led by his oldest 800. Mr. Burker w seried in 1466. Aline, young09t danghter of Charles and Caroline Joyce, by whom be is sorvived.
Among the decorations possessed by the deceased were the 8rd class of the Swedish "Vusa" Order, the fad olass Osmadieb, the Norwegian Orders of the Polar Star and St. Oloff, and the Crown of Italy.

The shareholders, who subscribed £100,oro fourteen months ago to the new i88de of Walker and Meimaracbi, Limited, are indignant because tbe board of directors bas decided to limit the dividend of five per cont., which bas jnot been declared, to the old sharebolders. The London board of directors of this company remain domb and do information is vouch-afed to the onfortapate sbarebollers in this country, who see their share: falling steadily. Some say that Mr. Constantine Meimaracbi intends to re-igo bis position on the company, while others assert that be will remain to guide the fortades of the company to a more prosperous ingne. The position of the local board of directors vis-4- vis the London board appears to be in a very in. definire state and, in fact, nobody knows what is going on at all.

The sbarebolders, who subsorihed in February last year to the now i8gne, and whose money enabled the board of direotors to porchase the property in the Roe Madabagh, balf of which bas realised op to now £26,000, see that this profit bas belped towards paying the dividend, which has just been declared, and are Dow asking where th-y are to come in. These onfortonate people have op to now looked to the local board of directors to help the ci mpady ont of the diffivalties enrroopdirg it. It will be romem hored that only a sbort time ago there was a largely attended meeting of the local sbarebilder: io Cairo, wbereat it was decided that it would be in the intere-ts of the com. pany it iho London board were aboliebet and the entire management concentrated in Ezypt. Since that resolation was arrived at nothing has been done in order to give effect to it, and the general feeling is one of atter bopelessnesk at the ontlook. The situation is more s nooying beoa 088 the company, from a commercial poin' of view, is doing very well both at Cairo add Alexandria.

y glutin Pasha, who is personally acquainted with His Majesty, as a perfect likevese.

div.head: NATIONALIST PRESS
div.p: THE LATEST ADDITION.

"Gel" (Cuiro) write: :--Yoar i8gne describing the 'inaagaral tea" given by the creator of the "Egyptian Standard" contained the sperohes of the interesting gladiators who are to edit the English and French editions of this amusing quotidian. Like most other British residents in Cairo who read your version of the ovations then delivered, I WAA bogely sorpri-ed by the seriousness with which M. Charles Rody and his Frenoh colleague proolaimed tbem-elves champions of the Nation. alist idea. I had always imagined that this was a partionlarly d ffi salt coontry to understand, thit pomorons wiiters and administrators had given matually contradictory versions of its needs, and that even Mr. J. M. Robertson, M.P., armed witb all the prestige of one who has to his own satisfaction demolished the Deity, had confessed himself anable to form any defiite opinion as to the best medioine for an ailing race. It is true that this dis tipgaisbed practitioner ba', pending further researcher, prescribed a little pallia-ive of his own, but I do not imagine that he believes implicitly in its efficacity...

Bat bere are foor men, a Frenchman, an Alsatian, a Swiss, and an Irishmann, alik, agreed on the needs of the body politic," said I to myself after rer ding the first few pombers of the "Egyptian Standard." Marvellous arani mity intensifie t by the Celtio glamour of Mr. Moloney's Natii nalist leaders and the more Teutonio solidity that marks Mr. Charles Rody's juos at the expense of a certain Mr. We. If I may be allowed & gastronomio metapbor, Mr. Rady supplies the beer and ch 9880, Mr. Moloney the arquebangh and Irish stew which regale the participants in the intellectual bar qaets supplied free of cost to subscribers till the 15th inst., whila Lord Cromer, tha Briti b Ocsapation, the "Times," th, "Esyptian Guzette," swad Pasha Zigbloul, and all who vontare to diff sr from Mr. We seoopdog-w9 refer of cour88 to Ma-tapba Pasba Komelmerve as joints from which slices are carved with speed and dexterity by the Pasha aided by a well-disciplined and expert staff Bat is this ananimi'y the onani. mity if koowledge or is it discipline ? I dare not approuch Mustapha Pasha on the subject and most therefore propound this vion--ander correction, viz., that the Pasba bar, not to pat too fino a point opon it, bireu a troupe of four able bodied gladiators - M. de St. Agan as Spadassin, M. He-toor as Lunequenet, Mr. Rady as Scbweizer, and Mr. Moloney as Gillowglass--and that the ananimity of these gentlemen is to be compared with that of the followers of Gwenwynwyn (a Welsh Nationalist, I believe) who "... Hired some magnanimous heroes-all fire Who lived but to emite and bo smitten for hire."

Io th45 case, Sir, the views expressed by these gentlemen after six w-eks' study of the Egyptian problem must be taken merely as war crio', "full of sound and fary" bat signifying rotbing in the way of matared koowledge.

div.head: UNITED EGYPTIAN LANDS.
div.p: ADDITIONAL LAND ACQUIRED AT RODAH ISLAND.
The statutory meeting of the United Egyptian Lands, Limited, was held on the 26th February at Salisbnry H0040, London Wall, E. C.
The Secretary (Mr. F. J. Asbury) having read the notice convening the meeting, | TheChairman (Mr. Gerald A. Sheppard) said:

The statatory meeting of a company is, as yon sro well aware, a formal one imposeł by law, and is generally bold in saob early days of h company's existence that it is not usgally p388ible to say a great deal. It is, bowever, always a good opportunity for the sbarebulders to meet thair directors, and we, on this side of the table, are very glad to havothat opportunity. The chairman of this company, M jor-General Sir Joho Ardagh, is absent in Egyp", and the last time I b9&rd from him, I regret to say, he was seriously ill, bat I trust he will soon recover. The other directors, Colonel Vylmar and Mr. Holland, are both ia Exypt on to company's business. Mr. Holland has been ap. poiute i managing director of this company, while Mr. Mayer, another director, wboze name is on the prospectus, has been called away to India on ve y pressing personal aff sirs. Mr. Briscoe, whom I am gla i tu huve bere at this meeting, jjined the board quite recently. There are probably fow gentlemen who buvo a greater experience than Mc. Brisco; in legal matters in Egypt, and ho has carried on his professioa there for msoy yoars. At the present moment I do not intend to say a great deal, as the board bas inviced you to an extraordinary general meeting filowing opon this, at which I have to discuss an important piece of basi. Doss. You will notice in the report that the total number of shares allotted was 422,716. They were largely over applied for, notably in Egypt. The allotment was made simolty2900sly in this country and Euyut, and tha process expedited matters considerab'y, and I have no doabt that it also gave considerable laboar to the Telegraph Company. The initial expenses of any ompany are natarally large when you have an lerw.iting commissions to p.y. You will see by the report that they smooted to £15,00. Agrin, o company that requires bearer warrants bus to meet the expenses of the Island Rivenne stamps-hut is, about £7,500. Advertising and the cost of promoting come to over £9,000. Hwever, all these charges are now over, an i we may say that we are fairly lannched on our career. In the prospectos you will notice we had options offered as over various properties, one of which was the Kom-el.Akbbar, and the other is only noticed in a small paragrapb, Rodab Island, 55,000 metres. The first properig is an agrical. taral property, and we have most encouraging reports apon it from our expert adviser, Mr. Paull. The local board have initiated a scheme for dealing wi b this property, the details of whijh I do not think I will enter into, as perhaps it would not be in the inter 34ts of the company to divolge them, but the profits on it will be a very sabstantial return on our ou lay. The payments we had to make in reepest of this property and tbe preliminary expenses Altogether amounted to mora than the money received on the share capital uccoaut. Wo have, however, fuand tha money to meet these commitments, and before long there will be & call falling dae. As to Rodah Island, the oth a option whioh we have exercised that is a building property, but most of my remarks on this property I wish to leave antil the extraor. rinary general meeting. Hwover, I will say this, that by those who are in the know in Exypt we have been congratulated opon acquiring this property. It was put in the prospectas at 65,000 metres, bat when we came to deal with it we found that we could obtain more on very reasonable terme ; in fact, the total was 221,101 metres roaghly. Th island, which was ouly formerly accessible by boats, has now been connected with Cairo by a bridge, so that it is a permanently integral part of that city, and one advantage is thi', that this bridg: riquires no opening for the river traffi', which is the great drawb.ok op the other bridge over the Nile. Therefore, ** yoa will 018 ly anderstan', the land traffic voed dover require to be interrupted, and the trams can now, without interraption, uroceed, 88 also can other vehicular traffic. We have a map, and from that you will see that our property is on th3 oathern oud, and the bridge comes over **!0tly where our property is. The price appears bigb, no doubt, but when I tell you hat the same pople that we brought it from bave bought some back at a vastly higher price, with optiung on other pieces, you will see that perhaps we have not done a bed deal. Before I move that the report be received, I maut congratulate the shareholders on the personnel of the local board. Daring the many years I hive been connected with Exyptian matters I bave intimately known Mr. Carver and Mr. Paall, Mr. Carver is the head of one of the most important English basineas firms in Alexandria, and his experience of Egypt is | lifelong Mr. Paull since 1894 hug managed land in Egopt, and acted as a tvisor in agri oultoral matters to varioag people with conspi. 09098 euc 3888, whilat Mr. Sarsook is a member of a well-known Syrian family, long resident in Egypt; so that I think the local board oun bardly be ornag-ed in experience in matters Egyptiun. I am now going to move that the report b. received. After it is seconded I wbull be very glad to answer any questions share: holder's wonld like to ask.
Mr. Briscoe seconded the resolution, which W 18 carried onanimously.

EXTRAORDINARY MEETING. Following upon the statatory meeting, an extraordinary general meeting of the ormpany was held for the purpose of considering, and, if thiaght fit passing, the following resolations :-"Thut the capital of the company ba incre4ned to £1 100,000 by the creation of 5 0000 new, Ordinary shares of £l each."

Mr. G. A. Shuopard, who again presided, said: You have had the notice convening the meetirg read, and the resolution which will be put eventually, and I ought to explain to you why the board is asking you to authorise the doubling of the capital after such a short exigter ce. To begin with, I must take you back to the prosj ectas, wherein it was stated that an option cold be secured by this company, at a satisfactory price, on 55,000 metres op Rodab Igland. I have already told you that that 55,000 metres has been increased four fold to 2:20,000 metre-. W: kuow, of course, that if we » cq vired his option the capital originally aske i tor- £0,00)-wonld be inadequate, hnt, what we did not know was wheber the R dab [!: d property was a good one to acquire or not. This matter had to be gone into thoroughly by our experts before we goald decide,

and there was no time to do that before the date I fisert for the is ao of the prospectos; but now that we have exercised this option we have got to pay for it and wa have undertaken, so hject to ynar an'horitation, to pay balf in shares and half in ca-b. This, as you will easily anderstand, makes it nece8&ry to 18800 more sbares, ag all ho other shure: bave already been taken ap; 80 we are going to ask you to authorise

h = increase to £1,00,000 by the creation of 500 000 now Oediasry shares of £l each. That I does not mean to say, however, that we are going to inade them at once. In the first place, to pay for tbiproperty we have to ingne to the vendore 29 :,700 shares. Th*t is very nearly 300,000. In payment of the other halfdevelopments and genera' expe 1898 – we shall have to iR800 some more shares for cash in the fatare. Before deciding on the time and method we think that we should liki to wait on cir. comstances The sharehold 1rs who received this rather bald statement in the noticeaboot the increase to £ ,00.00-mngt have had 04088 for surprise, goeing how early it is in th: existence of the company and how large the increase is; huI think that when you have my explai a'ion of the need for this orea. tion you will see that we have only done what was necessary. You will see th4t by isgging or creating 'h 198 500 ono baras we are going to pay a part of the cost of a very valuabe property - property of which we all have oar-elves very little doubt, and I am told by those who advire as about it that i- will very early enable 08 to realise dividends for this company. I do not think I have any bing more to say ou this matter. We have had the land already cat op ioto plots. div.head: EGYPT'S TRADE
div.p: STATISTICS FOR 1906.

With the publication of the Customs Ratorne for December, the figares relating to the exports and imports daring 1906 are available, and a brief study of sach statistios may possibly not be withoat interest to some of our member, says the Joarnal of the British Chamber of Commerce.

The total imports cleared through the Customs dariog the twelve months opding S.S. December last were valaed at L.E. 24 010,705, being an increase over 1905 of L.E. 3,446,719. These latter figares are nearly two and a half times larger than the expansion in 1905, though they fall copriderably short of the increase of LE. 8,806,894 which. was noted when the retards for 1904 were compared with 1903. As we bave previously pointed oat, the rate of progress shown daring 1904 was to some extent an artificial one dae iš the main to overstocking by mo arohants, and it is, tberefire, only nataral to fiod that the pace was not maintsined during the last two years.

Before dealing with the varions Customs classifi:ations, w. give the osoal table showing the relative positions of the countries whiob have supplied E:ypt with the largest amount of goods during the past four years. The retards for the Uuited Kingdom and France inolude the figures relating to their respective possessions in the Mediterranean.

In view of the steady drop whiob hae 0 oarred during recent yeurs in the United Kingdom'o share of th: total Egyptian importa, it is satisfactory to note that the decline was arrested in 1906 and that the home country improved her percentage from 33.1 to 88 5. France increased ber proportion by nearly one per cent, whilst Gorming's trade expanded by 1.1% and Belgiam by 1.3 %.

Metals. The largest increase in any of the Castomy fifteen categories oocarred in the metal division, where the große valne of the olearancos amounted to L. E. 3,868,747 or L.E. 1,031,99% more than in 1905.

Iron and Iron Goods. The quantity of girders an 1 ocber beavy forms of iron classified according to weight, land-d in Egypt during the 12 minths ander revision reached 113,589 tops, of the yaloe of L.E. 700 480.In 19:15 .be figures were 89,439 ton =.B 49.9.6. The value of the iron good», of which the weigh:8 @Dit rroorded by the Co.toms, W48 L.E. | 1,146,648 against L.E. - 55,441 in 1905. 1 Machinery A zents dealing in machinery

Cannot complain that orders were scarce last year, for clearances under this heading (1000motives and rolling stook being exoladed) wore L. E. 371,571 to the good compared with | 1905. Io the Agrisaltaral Machinery division, Great Britain was oredited with L.E. 184,223, Switzerland L.R. 19.63, Germany L.E. 11,824 and amrion L.B 4.290.
Locomotives and Rolling Stock. The deliveries ander th. 8: bandu gs word olude apon 91% lower than in 1995, the decrea e being L.E. 43,6:3.
TIMBER AND Coal. This classification which includes furgitate comes out second on the list of increases with again of L E 349,068 or 13 % above the clearances for 1905.
Timber. The arrivals of timber during the yeur were valued at L.E. 1,318,670, being a decrease of L.E. 10,649 compared with 1905. The increase in 1905 over 1904 was L.E. 127,188.
Coal The coal returne, which in 1905 showed a loss of L.E. 63,685, completely recovered their position last year, when the figures were po less than L.E. 228,431 bigher than during 1905

Furniture. The opening of certain large hote's undoubtedly contributed to the extra. or lipary increase of L.E 106,445 in the furniture fignres. As a matter of pos ible interest, we may mention thit Ingt yar Buyp receiver fornitore to the valne of L.E. 110,773 from Austria, LB. 102,901 from France, L.E. 97 555 from Great Britain, L.E. 61 222 from Italy, and L.B. 51,988 from Gormaby.

CABBAIA. The very rapid rate of expaneton which we noted at the end of 1996 in the 09roul imports was not maintained daring 1906. though the shipments, De. vertboloss, aboved the substantial gain of L.E. 278,976.

Flour. As we shoald Datarally expect, Ajar was the principal contribator to the gaio ip the cereal class. Compared with 1905, 161,455,024 kilos valaed at L.E. 1, 315,190 were received against 131,919,256 kilo=1.B. 1,064,755, the increase thus being 29, 33,768 kilo: =L.E. 25,435. France, of coarise, largely bouefi ed by the additional trade, though it is distinctly gratilying to fiud that Great Britain foood & sale here for 11,237 257 kilo sa L.E. 8°,989 against 4,304,746 ki.o: LE 35,166 in 1905. We have repeatedly drawn the attention of home millers to the extent of ths trade done bere in Al Jar, and we are pleased to note that our off its bave not been wasted.

Other Cereals. The quantity of wheat brought into the conutry lost year was 19,489,602 kilor, or 10,552,281 kilos less than duriog the previ us twelve months. On the other band, barley with 30,882 939 kilos was 7,1 7,511 kilos to the good, the rice figares ut. 46.183,513 kilos being also bigher by 5,360,307 kilos.

CHEMICAL MANUBES. The warning4 which have mure than once appeared in the Financial Adviser's report apropos of ibo danger of overoropping have evidently done good, for the Castoms returns clearly sbow the strides whi h the trade in artificial madures is making in this cjuntry, Uuder the heading "Chemical Prodaots & Pharmacoatical Preparations, eto." the imports during 1906 amountd to L.E. 260 927 compared with L.E. 162,411 in 1905. and there can be no doubt that this increase is almost entirely dae to additional shipments of artifisial o apgres.

Textiles. This Cnatoms classification is raspousible for L.E. 47,997 of the total expan sion in the import trade during 1916. EXPORTS

Egypt's total expirts diring the twelve months aning 318* Dscember last were valuat *t L.E. 24,877, 8', bing a gain of L.E 15169.5 c mpar d with 1995. Cotton. The cott n-hipments w?re 6,696, 69 #nimr:=L.E. 0,28 004 ag iust 6,527,85 cantarsz'.8. 15, 06.147 the provinus twelve non'be, It will be observed that the average price por oantar during 1906 wąs L.E. 8.065, whereas in 1905 it was only 4.8. 2.421.

div.head: Circulaire H. De Vries et Boutigny
div.p: Le Cairo, Jeadi 7 Mars 1907. Le taux de l'escompte libre à Londres est toujours d 4 8/4 poor oent. An Stock Exchange, le Consolidé anglais a baissé hier de non moins de 1/4 86 3/8. L'Unifiée est restée invariée A 102 1/8. La National Bank a perdı 1/4 à 27 7/8. La Daïra a gagné 1/8 à 16 5/8. L'Agricole est demeurée inobangea à 9 3/8, ainsi que la Delta Light à 11 1/2.
A Paris, le Crédit Foncier Egyptien & on. core rétrogradé de 2 franos & 750. La Banque d'Athènes a également recalé de 2 francs à 187

loi, la séance d'anj iurd'hui a été, au début surtout, presque exactement la répétition de celle d'bier. Tendance générale lourde, le marobé subissant, d'one part, le contre-conp de la tendo per favorable des Boarses de Londres et de Paris, d'autre part, les conséquences d'une position de place encombréą gno la réconte liquidation n'avait pas soffisamment dé. blayée, et enfio, en troisième liea, les effats des noavelles émissions qui menacent, malgré toat, de ne pas s'arrêter. Toutefois, la clorare s'est faite dans des conditions moing maovaises que no somblaient l'indiquer los di-positions pen rasgarantes de l'ouverture. C'est peut-être là an indica que noas aurons des séances meilleures et que la crise toacha à sa fin.

Dans le compartiment des Barques, la Na. tional a encore molli 8 27 11/16 8/4 et l'Agricole à 9 1/16 1/8. La Cassa di soonto a o! . taré à 871.872: Le Comptoir Financier a faibli à 7 1/16. LBanque d'Athènes est revendo & 134 135. L: Banque d'Orient s'est raffermie à 133-134. Les parts de la Société Générale Egyptienne ont filéobi à 88.
La Crédit Funcier a 6é délaissé à 748, de même que la Daïra à 16 1/8. La Bébéra est reg. tée à 40 et l'Union Foncière & 5 15/16 6.
L'Immobilière s'est alourdie à 386-397. L'Allotmont a été mions tenu à 3 1/16 1/8.

L98 E-treprises Inmobilières et Travans ont clo'aré à 6 7/; lear part est remontda à 109. L'Epargne lu nobilière a été ramenée à 8 8/8 at sa part à 93.100. L'Expro88 Nilo & torminé à 4 3/4 ; sa part s'est maintenne à 130.
La Delta Light & fléchi à 11 1/4 et les Jouissances à 278 279. La Brasserie des Pyra. mides s'est alourdie à 131. Les privilégiées Tramways d'Alexandrie ont baissé à 183 et les dividendes à 846.
Dans le groape des valeurs botelières, les Nuogovich ont perdu environ 3/4 d 29. Los Egyptian ont rétrogradé 13 1/8. les Upper Egypt à 4 8/16 les Excelsior à 4 1/2 et lear part à 1 1/8 1/4.

Parmi les petites valeurs, la Delta Land s'est encore tassée à 8 15/16 4. Los Estates ont égalemont faibli à 9 3/16-1/4 et lear part à 32 3/4. Les New Bzyptian ont fésbi à 23 sh, les Markets & 26 sh., les Abdy a 1 1/16 1,8 et les Hooker à 1 1/16.
Nous détachong date correspondance de Londres, on date da ler Mars, le passage Baivant :

"Le Stock Exchange en est tonjoard à attendre ane impulsion qui puisse le faire sortir de l'inaction dans l.quelle il végète depois plusieurs semaines. Un changement à cet état de choses semble difficile tant qu'ane détente sérieuse no ne sera pe8 prodoite sur le marché monétaire. Ba outre, l'état de la place de Now York et la situation politique en Russie donnent lieu à quelques appréhensions.

"Pour le moment, c'est la oberté de l'argent ! qui continue à barrer spé sialıment le chemin de la hangse au Consolidé et autres fonds d'Etat. La sitaation de la Barque d'Angleterre contione, il est vrai, à s'améliorer ; mais les conditions du marché monétaire ne semblent pas se modifier. L98 eapitaax laicsés à la dig. position des affsires sont si rares qu'il faut payer 5% pour les prêts au jour le jour et 47/8 pour le chart terme et que le taux de l'es. compte libre reste à 4 3/4 poar cent.

"Le compartiment des valeurs égyptiepper&0 Stock Exchange persiste à rester calme, bien que le bas prix des titres devienne de plas en intéressant at soit certainement appelé à attirer l'attention dans un bref délai."
Une de plos.
Da annonce de Londres la formation d'ope) Société anonyme 8008 la dénomination de "Société Anglo-Bgyptienne d'habitations économiques."
La nouvelle Compagnie, qui a été enregistrée le 18 Février 1907, est au capital de £30,850, représenté par 20,000 actions de £4 at 5,000 parts de fondateur à 1 shelling.

Les actionnaires de la Banque d'Orient sont convoqués en assemblée générale ordinaire le 25 Mars courant, au siège social à Athènes. A l'ordre du jour : rapport du conseil ; approbation des comptes de l'exeroice 1906; fixation da dividende ; modifications aux articles 31 et 86 des Statuts et proposition tendant à aug. monter le capital social de 10 millions de fran08.

- L'assemblée générale ordinaire de la Ban que de Salonique est fixé au 28 Mars conrapt au siège social à Salopique. A l'ordre du jar: rapport de conseil ; approbation des comptes de l'exercice 1906 ; fixntion da dividenre ; proposi'ion tondant à porter le ospital social de 8 à 10 millions de frapon. Le dividende qui sera proposé est, dit-on, de 10 %, comme pour l'exercice précédent.

div.head: AVIS
div.p: Nous portons à la connaissanoa da publio qao deox obèques émis le 7 mars courant à notre ordre por la National Bank of Egypt du Csire, l'un de L.E. 415 164/1000 par le Finanoial Seoretary War Offi se, l'autre de L.E. 501.400/1000 par le Ministère des Financer, o endos.és par nous en blanc ont bé perdas hier nu Caire dans l'après-midi.
Nous avons immédiatement prévang. le Bangaes de ne pas payer on 0800mpter les dite chèques et nous mettons en garde le poblic contre toute tentative de recouvrement de l part de qai que ce soit :
Gustav BBACH & Co SUCO Alexandrie, le 8 Mars 1907.

div.head: TO OUR VISITORS
div.p: The Egyptian Gazette has much pleasure in presenting to its subscribers the accompanying description of some of the many interesting routes by which they may travel homewards. Great care has been taken to arrange them as accurately and concisely as possible, and it will be found that none of them are fraught with difficulty. In choosing the route home there are several things to be considered. To begin with there is the difference in climate between Egypt and the various points at which you may arrive in Europe.

This depends partly upon the month in which you leave Egypt, for Cairo in January may be a little warmer than the Riviera and possibly not so warm as Sicily, but in March it will be warmer than Rome, and more uniformly warm than many other places in Europe. Many people leave Egypt far too early in the year, for as a rule the weather in April and May is perfect. The warmest place to go to on leaving Egypt is Sicily.

Some will want to take into consideration the number of days to be spent at sea, and we therefore subjoin a list shewing the time occupied on each of the various routes between Egypt and the Continent of Europe.
They are as follows:—
The long sea routes—from Port Said or Alexandria to Plymouth, Southhampton, London or Liverpool—occupy about 14 days. The short ones are as follows:—

The steamers of the P.& O., the Egyptian Mail S.S,. Co., North German Lloyd, Orient, and Messageries Maritimes are the largest. The Anchor, British India, Bibby and Henderson Lines are also excellent, and their steamers are largely patronised by travellers to Egypt.
As regards the train journeys from Cairo, the shortest is that to Alexandria, without change (3 hours). That to Port Said can now be made without change in 4 ½ hours.

The least expensive way to England is by the Moss, Papayanni, Prince, and Westcott lines of steamers from Alexandria to Liverpool. The German Levant line has also good steamers from Alexandria to Hamburg.

The quickest through Continental routes are by P.& O. Brindisi express from Port Said, by the Egyptian Mail S.S. Co., from Alexandria to Marseilles and the Austrian Lloyd Trieste Vienna express from Alexandria.

As regards heavy luggage, it must be borne in mind that very little luggage is allowed free on the railways of Europe, but there are several good and responsible forwarding agents in Egypt who undertake at a fixed charge to deliver packages to any address in Europe. The Egyptian Mail S.S. Co., have also made arrangements whereby luggage can be collected and sent to any address.

The quickest manner of getting to Europe from Port Said is undoubtedly by the fast Mail Steamers "Osiris" and "Isis" to Brindisi. One of these leaves Port Said every week, as soon as possible after receiving the Indian mails from the great liner arrived from Bombay.

These small but comfortable ships have enormously powerful engines, and attain a very high rate of speed. They are called the "Ferry Boats" having been specially built to carry the British mail from Port Said to Brindisi. If you are going straight through to England you will find the train waiting at Brindisi which will take you to Calais without changing. It has complete arrangements for sleeping and eating on board, and you should arrive in London on the fifth day from leaving Port Said.

div.head: SICILY.
div.p: The direct route to Sicily is by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers which leave Alexandria weekly for MESSINA, where one takes train to TAORMENA, one of the most charming and popular places on the island. Giardini is the station at which to alight, and the drive up to Taormina is most delightful, occupying about one hour. In and around the town is much to interest the visitor. The theatre is of Greek origin, but restored under the Romans. CATANIA is the starting place for the ascent of Etna, and here also is a fine Cathedral. The Greek, Roman, and Saracenic remains that are found all over the island, are an endless sources of pleasure. SYRACUSE has an interesting history, having been a Greek city, which was designed by Demosthenes in B.C. 413, and taken by the Romans in B.C. 212, when Archimedes was slain—his tomb is to be seen. The cathedral was once an ancient pagan temple. PALERMO, with about 300,000 inhabitants, is the capital of the Island, and enjoys a delightful climate. Much of interest is to be found in this fine city. The Palazzo Reale is of Saracenic origin and close to it the church of S. Giovannia degli Eremiti with its picturesque cloisters. The Cathedral, Museum, Botanic Gardens, Villa Giulia and Royal Park are also worth a visit.

div.head: CENTRAL ITALY.
div.p: The fine steamers of the North German Lloyd leave Alexandria every Wednesday during the season for Naples, the voyage being only 3 days.

NAPLES is also reached in 10 hours from Palermo by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers, which leave daily. One cannot approach Naples or leave it without wishing to explore some of its islands, besides the lovely places on its bay—Castellamare and Sorrento. The small steamer that takes you to Sorrento [you can drive too] will take you on to Capri.

From Naples to ROME is a train journey of but five hours. All who can will devote at least one week to visiting the many historical and interesting portions of the Eternal City, whose charms and beauties are too well-known to need comment here.

Leaving the Eternal City with much regret, a railway journey of five hours brings you to FLORENCE, where another week can well be spent admiring the City of Flowers and its surrounding country. In Florence itself the churches and galleries are of absorbing interest, whilst the local promenades and excursions should not be omitted. The Cascine is the most attractive and fashionable promenade in Florence, whilst the Viale dei Colli, one of the finest walks in Europe, opened 35 years ago, goes winding up through the hills a distance of four miles. The most delightful excursion outside Florence is that to Vallombrosa, with its Monastery 3,300 feet above the sea level. This is made first by ordinary train from Florence to St. Ellero, thence by cog-wheel railway to Saltino. The ascent through groves of oaks takes an hour, and most striking panoramas are unfolded to view.

PISA is easily reached from Florence in about 2 hours ; here there is a fine Cathedral and the Leaning Tower. A stay of at least one night should if possible be made in order to enjoy the view from the Campanile at sunset.

VIAREGGIO. One of the most delightful places on the Italian Riviera near Pisa and on the main line from Rome to Genoa. It is a very convenient half-way house between Egypt and England, and where living is reasonable and the air and surroundings exceptionally good.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY
div.p: GENOA (La Superba).—The most picturesque and interesting city in Italy, with the record of having one of the lowest death averages of European cities and a phenomenally equable temperature—warm in winter and deliciously cool breezes from the surrounding mountains and the Mediterranean in summer.

The patriarchal home of Italy's most ancient nobility, whose palaces, gardens, and famous collections of statuary, frescoes, and paintings, are a constant delight to thousands of travellers who annually sojourn in Genoa. Then there are the superbly decorated medieval churches containing exquisite marble columns and historical paintings, and the incomparable Campo Santo filled with its wonderful tombs.
From Genoa to Milan is a matter of only three hours by rail.

MILAN is a good centre for Northern Italy before making the tour of the Lakes. The Cathedral is the principal attraction, with its beautiful windows illustrating the History of the Bible. The public gardens and the monumental cemetery are also worth a visit.

Between Bologna and Milan and only an hour and a half from Milan is SALSOMAGGIORE, a renowned health resort on account of its thermal springs, change trains at Borgo San Domino and in half-an-hour you are at Salsomaggiore.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY (Continued) and The ITALIAN LAKES.
div.p: VENICE is a 5 hours journey by rail from Milan, and one of the most delightful places imaginable to pass a quiet stay. The total absence of vehicular traffic strikes one as very strange; no horse, cart, carriage or bicycle is to be seen, and yet there is the sound of life at every turn. The approach to Venice from the Adriatic is unlike that of any other sea port. The town seems to be gradually, like Aphrodite, born of the sea. No hills behind, no stretches of rock, but first the tops of Campaniles appear above the horizon, then slowly the whole glittering town rises like a fairy mirage out of the calm lagoon.
Going northwards from Milan you make the tour of the beautiful Italian lakes.
COMO, the birthplace of the younger Pliny, is reached in one-and-a-quarter hours by train by way of Monza.

Boats leave Como frequently for the other towns on the lake, which is very beautiful, and the scenery on either side going up the lake is most enchanting. CERNOBBIO is a charming spot; then come Tremezzo, Cadenabbia, and Menaggio with the prettily-situated town of Bellaggio opposite. The walk from Tremezzo along the shore of the lake to Menaggio is most enjoyable. A steam tram runs from Menaggio to Porlezza on Lake Lugano in three-quarters of an hour, then steamer to Lugano in two-and-three-quarter hours.

div.head: SWITZERLAND.
div.p: Switzerland, the heart of Europe, has been described as "A cluster of delights and grandeurs."

LUGANO is some 20 miles from Como and reached by train in one-and-a-half hours. It has a population of 10,000 people and is charmingly situated on the Lake of Lugano, amidst lovely Italian scenery. Around it rise M. San Salvatore, M. de Caprino.and M. Generoso.

LOCARNO may be reached by rail from Bellinzona in forty minutes. This pretty town, situated at the top of Lake Maggiore, has a mild climate and is an excellent winter resort. The church Madonna del Sasso, situated above the town, is worth a visit, as it contains interesting paintings, "Entombment," by Ciseri, and 'Tho Flight into Egypt," by Bramantion.
LUCERNE—A striking picture on the Lake of Lucerne facing the Rigi and Pilatus and the snow-clad Alps.
In and around the town the walks are charming, and the excursions to be made from Lucerne by boat, rail, etc., are very numerous.

The Lake of Lucerne abounds in delightful excursions, those to the Rigi, Pilatus, Burgenstock and Sonnenberg needing a special visit each. Other excursions on the lake can be made by steamer, and the ever-changing scenery on the trip from Lucerne, to Fluelen is a source of delight to the lover of nature.

BRUNNEN, charmingly situated on the most beautiful part of the Lake of Lucerne, commands magnificent views of lake and mountain scenery. Along the Lake of Uri from Brunnen to Fluelen runs the famous Axentrasse.

THUN (on the Lake of Thun) half an hour from Berne and one hour from Interlaken. Quiet and quaint; sheltered from winds; just the place to rest and recuperate. Beautiful walks, through woods, and along the lake shore. Kursaal, Concernts, Casino, Races, Tennis, Boating, etc.

THE BERNESE OBERHAND. – INTERLAKEN, a favourite summer resort and the best centre for making excursions in the Oberland, abounding in fine walks and views. There is a magnificent view of the Jungfrau from the Hoheweg, a fine avenue of walnut trees, the chief resort of visitors. Interlaken is also not far from the famous waterfalls, Giessbach, Trummelbath and Staubbach. Then also the glaciers of Grindelwald and view from Murren and the Schynige Platte are sights not to be missed.

CHATEAU D'OEX. 3,500 ft above the sea on the new Electric Railway between Montreux and Interlaken, surrounded by magnificent scenery, with pure dry air. Much frequented by English people in Summer and Winter.

ZURICH on the Gothard route. Direct communication with Northern Europe. Largest town in Switzerland, beautifully-situated on the lake of Zurich. Theatres. Big Concern Halls. Boating on the lake. Excellent schools. The National Museum.

div.head: GREECE and IONIAN ISLES.
div.p: Many people visit Greece after wintering in Egypt, as it is so easily reached from Alexandria ; the climate in April is charming. The best steamers are those of the Khedivial Mail Co. and the Russian Steam Navigation Co.

If possible tourists should arrange to be in Athens for the Orthodox Easter in order to witness the Good Friday and Easter Eve ceremonies, and to be present at the dancing on the Easter Tuesday festival held at Megara for which a special train is run from Athens.
It is worth while to spend a few days in CORFU on account of the beauty of the scenery. There is also good snipe and quail shooting to be had.

div.head: Supplement Commercial et Financier.
div.p: De "L'Egyptian Gazette"

Le Supplément Commercial et Financier de l' "Egyptian Gazette" paraît chaque Samed à midi, de façon à pouvoir être expédié par le paquebot autrichien. Il contient des revues complètes et impartiales du coton, des graines de coton, et du marché des valeurs; les dernières statistiques jusqu'à la veille de sa publication: des tableaux des fluctuations de la place et les copies des dépêches officielles envoyées à la Liverpool Cotton Association, etc etc
L'abonnement pour une année en Egypte coûte 1 L.E. y compris les frais de poste; pour l'étranger 10 P.T. de port en sus.
Les personnes qui connaissent les
Pilules du Docteur DEHAUT de Paris

n'hésitent pas à se purger, quand elles en ont besoin. Elles ne craignent ni le dégoût ni la fatigue, parce que, à l'opposé des autres purgatifs, celui-ci n'opère bien que lorsqu'il est pris avec de bons aliments et des boissons fortifiantes, telles que vin, café, thé. Chacun choisit, pour se purger, l'heure et le repas qui lui conviennent le mieux, selon ses occupations. La fatigue de la purgation étant annulée par l'effet de la bonne alimentation, on se décide aisément à recommencer autant de fois que cela est nécessaire.
5 fr. et 2 fr. 50
